highlights.para: This appendix contains a glossary of terms for use in GNOME documentation. The terms are listed in the following categories:

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para:
The glossary provides the following information for each term, where relevant:
Definition
A definition of the term in the context of the GNOME Desktop. If the term applies only to a specific type of documentation, the type of documentation is noted after the definition, in brackets. For example, [System administration documentation].
Usage
Grammatical and syntax guidelines for authors about how to use the term.
Tags
Guidelines for tag usage.
Example
One or more examples to illustrate how to use the term.
Note
Additional information such as exceptions, synonyms, and so on.

In general, terms that are listed in the American Heritage Dictionary do not appear in this glossary. However, if the definition in the American Heritage Dictionary is not clear enough, or if there is a specific variation of a term is used in the GNOME Desktop, the term appears in this glossary.
To suggest a term for inclusion in this glossary, send your request to docs@gnome.org.

sect1.title: GNOME Desktop Terms
sect1.para: This section contains terms that you use when you describe the user interface of the GNOME Desktop, with the exception of buttons.

varlistentry.term:
applet
applet, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A small application that resides on a panel. Applets usually have a simple user interface.
Prose tag rules. Use the application tag for the names of applets.
Each applet has a simple user interface that you can operate with the mouse or keyboard.
If you think that the term applet might be confusing in a particular context, use the more specific term panel applet.

varlistentry.term:
applet popup menu
applet popup menu, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para:
The popup menu that opens when you right-click on the handle of an applet, or on any blank area in an applet. Applet popup menus typically contain the following items:
Preferences
Help
Remove From Panel
Move
The applet popup menu can also contain applet-specific items.
Right-click on the Command Line applet to open the applet popup menu.

varlistentry.term:
application registry [System administration documentation]
application registry [System administration documentation], GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: The application registry is a location that contains text files that register applications.
The application registry for the GNOME Desktop is located in the /usr/share/gnome/application-registry directory.

varlistentry.term: assistant assistant, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: An interactive tool that helps you to perform a complex task. An assistant guides you through the steps required to perform the task. For example, the Evolution Setup Assistant guides you through the initial configuration process for the Evolution email client.
Normal text rules. Use title capitalization for assistant names.
Prose tag rules. Use the application tag for the name of an assistant.
You can use an assistant to configure an LDAP server.
Click on the Forward button on the Evolution Setup Assistant.
Do not use the following terms as synonyms for assistant:

varlistentry.term:
auto, prefix
auto, prefix, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A prefix that describes an action where the system does something for you to save you effort.
Do not hyphenate this prefix, or use the prefix as a separate word. For example do not use auto-complete, auto hide, and so on.

varlistentry.term:
autocomplete
autocomplete, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: To automatically complete a path or command name as you type. The Location field in a Nautilus window includes an autocomplete function.
The Command Line applet contains a history-based autocompletion function.
Do not hyphenate this term, do not use auto-complete.

varlistentry.term:
autogravity
autogravity, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A feature that enables your windows to expand automatically in the most suitable direction for display on your screen. Autogravity prevents your windows from expanding off your screen. Autogravity affects window display when a window expands as a result of a system action. For example, if you click on a tabbed section in a dialog, and the new tabbed section requires more space, then autogravity can control how the window expands.
Autogravity does not affect window display when you maximize a window.
Do not hyphenate this term, do not use auto-gravity.

varlistentry.term:
autohide
autohide, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: To automatically hide a user interface item when the item is not in use.
To set your panel to autohide, modify the properties of the panel.
Do not hyphenate this term, do not use auto-hide.

varlistentry.term:
autoindent
autoindent, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: To automatically indent text to the same tab stop position as the previous line in a file.
The gedit text editor contains an autoindent function.
Do not hyphenate this term, do not use auto-indent.

varlistentry.term: backtrace backtrace, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A text representation that details the current hierarchy of functions being called by an application. If an application crashes, you can use the backtrace to identify what code was being executed when the application crashed.
Bug Buddy automatically adds the core file or backtrace to the bug report.
Spell as one word, and do not hyphenate. Do not use back trace or back-trace.

varlistentry.term:
border
border, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: The border around a window. The titlebar and the border of a window are the components of the window frame.
Select this option to include the titlebar and border of a window in a screenshot.
Do not use the term edge as a synonym for border.

varlistentry.term:
button
button, GNOME Desktop term

row.entry: A user interface element that you use to start an action. There are many types of button in the GNOME Desktop. For more information about the types of button and the rules for their usage, see . Some buttons do not have labels, so you do not have a convenient reference term. Although a button does not have a name, there might be a tooltip for the button. If the text in the tooltip is appropriate, use that text as the button name.

entry.para: Use the guibutton tag for button names.
The History button is a feature of the Command Line applet.
When you refer to a button that has a specific identity but no textual label, use title capitalization for the button name.

varlistentry.term:
check box
check box, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A dialog element that you use to select or deselect an option.

Normal text rules.
Verb: Select, deselect, or choose, depending on the function that the check box fulfills.
Noun: Option.
Use the guilabel tag for the check box name.
Select the Create monochrome image option to create a screenshot in black and white.
Spell as two words, do not use checkbox.
Avoid using the term check box in your documentation. Use the term option instead.

varlistentry.term:
color selector dialog
color selector dialog, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A dialog that you use to select a color. When you click on a color selector button the color selector dialog is displayed.
Click on the Color to use button to display the color selector dialog.
Color selector dialog is a generic term for the dialog that is displayed when you click on a color selector button.

varlistentry.term:
color wheel
color wheel, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: The circular control on a color selector dialog that enables you to choose a color.
On the color selector dialog, use the color wheel or sliders to choose the color.

varlistentry.term:
column heading
column heading, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A heading for a table column in a dialog or window. Some column headings exhibit button-like behavior. For example, to sort the data in the Evolution Inbox, click on the heading of the column by which you want to sort the data.

Normal text rules.
Verb Phrase: Click on.
Noun: Column heading.
Use the guilabel tag for the names of column headings.
To sort the file types by filename extension, click on the Extension column heading.

varlistentry.term:
combo box
terms to avoid combo box

listitem.para: Do not use this term. Use the term drop-down combination box.

varlistentry.term: compose keyboard compose keyboard, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A compose keyboard is an onscreen keyboard that contains alphanumeric keys. You can use a compose keyboard to compose text by activating the keys on the keyboard.
The GOK compose keyboard is a standard alphanumeric keyboard.

varlistentry.term:
control
control, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: An instrument that you use to operate or guide the user interface. For example, radio buttons, sliders, check boxes, and so on are controls.
The controls theme option affects the appearance of controls in dialogs and applets.
In user documentation, do not use widget as a synonym for control.
Some controls reside in dialogs and in this situation you can refer to the controls as dialog elements or controls, depending on the context in which you are describing the controls.

varlistentry.term: criterion criterion, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A condition that is applied to an advanced search, a filter, or a virtual folder in Evolution Inbox. Advanced searches, filters, and virtual folders test for criteria that you specify. For example, you can create an advanced search to find messages from a particular address that contain particular text. To do this, you create an advanced search with two criteria. One criterion specifies the address of the sender, the other criterion specifies the text.
To add a criterion to the advanced search, click on the Add button.
You can also perform advanced searches that use more complex search criteria.
The plural of criterion is criteria. Do not use criteria to express the singular form of this noun.
Do not use rule or condition as synonyms for criterion.

varlistentry.term:
current viewport
current viewport, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: The viewport that is displayed on the GNOME Desktop.
The current viewport is highlighted with a checked background.

varlistentry.term:
current workspace
current workspace, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: The workspace that is displayed on the GNOME Desktop.
On the Workspace Switcher applet, the button that represents the current workspace is pressed in.

varlistentry.term: desktop desktop, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: The part of the GNOME Desktop where there are no interface graphical items, such as panels and windows.
Right-click on the desktop to open the Desktop menu.
Use desktop in the user interface, in Help, and in documentation body text.
See also desktop background, desktop environment, GNOME Desktop.

varlistentry.term: desktop backgrounddesktop background, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: The image or color that is applied to the desktop.
To change the desktop background, right-click on the desktop, then choose Change Desktop Background from the Desktop menu.
Use desktop background in the user interface, in Help, and in documentation body text.
See also desktop, desktop environment, GNOME Desktop.

varlistentry.term: desktop environmentdesktop environment, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para:
The totality of the following:
All windows, panels, and workspaces.
All libraries, applications, protocols, and so on that the GNOME Desktop uses.
Choose the GNOME Desktop from the list of available desktop environments.
The term desktop environment is used mostly, but not exclusively, in system administrator documentation and developer documentation.
See also desktop, desktop background, GNOME Desktop.

varlistentry.term: Desktop menuDesktop menu, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A menu that you can use to arrange items on your desktop.
Title capitalization for the term Desktop, lowercase letters for the term menu.
Use the guimenu tag for the term Desktop.
Right-click on the desktop to open the Desktop menu.
Use desktop in the user interface, in Help, and in documentation body text.

varlistentry.term: desktop objectdesktop object, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: An icon on your desktop that you can use to open your files, folders, and applications.
You can use desktop objects to provide convenient access to files, folders, and applications that you use frequently.

varlistentry.term:
desktop entry file [System administration documentation]
desktop entry file [System administration documentation], GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A data file that provides information about an item in a menu, a panel launcher, or a desktop object. Desktop entry files have a .desktop file extension.
The desktop entry file contains keywords which determine the location of the item in the menu hierarchy.

varlistentry.term:
dialog
dialog, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A popup window in which the user enters information or commands.
Apply title capitalization to the name of a dialog.
Use the guilabel tag for the dialog name.
Use the Panel Properties dialog to specify the color and image for the panel background.
Some dialogs in the GNOME Desktop do not have a title. If the dialog does not have a title, you can assign the dialog an appropriate title in your documentation.

varlistentry.term:
dialog element
dialog element, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A component part of a dialog. Examples of dialog elements are: check boxes, command buttons, tabs, and tabbed sections.
The Background tabbed section contains the following dialog elements.
You can shorten dialog element to element when you are clearly referring to a dialog element.

varlistentry.term:
dialog pane
dialog pane, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: An area in an application window that resembles a dialog, and where you enter data.
Enter the information for the submenu in the Basic tabbed section on the dialog pane.

varlistentry.term:
directory entry file [System administration documentation]
directory entry file [System administration documentation], GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A data file that provides information about a menu. Directory entry files have a .directory file extension.
The directory entry file specifies the details for the menu, such as a name, a tooltip, and an icon.

varlistentry.term:
drawer
drawer, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A collapsible extension of a panel.
You can move objects between panels and drawers.

varlistentry.term:
drop-down combination box
drop-down combination box, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A text box with a drop-down list attached. You can either type a value, or choose a value from the list.

listitem.para: Verb Phrase: Use the drop-down-name drop-down combination box to specify.
Noun: Drop-down combination box.

entry.para: Use the guilabel tag for the name of a drop-down combination box.
Use the Directory to save images in drop-down combination box to specify the directory in which to save your images.
Do not use the term combo box.

varlistentry.term:
drop-down list
drop-down list, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A dialog element that you use to select one of several items. A drop-down list has a drop-down button that you use to display the available items.

Normal text rules.
Verb Phrase: Use the drop-down-list-name drop-down list to specify.
Noun: Drop-down list.
Use the guilabel tag for the name of a drop-down list.
Use the Panel size drop-down list to specify the size of the panel.
You cannot type in a drop-down list.

varlistentry.term: drop-down section drop-down section, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A dialog element that you use to display additional dialog elements. You click on the associated text to display the additional items.

Normal text rules.
Verb Phrase: Click on.
Noun: Drop-down section.
Use the guilabel tag for the name of a drop-down section.
Use the Save in folder drop-down list, or click on the Browse for other folders drop-down section, to specify the location of the saved image.

varlistentry.term:
emblem
emblem, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A small icon that you can add to an item in a Nautilus window.
To add an emblem to an item, drag the emblem to the item.

varlistentry.term:
field
field, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para:
A dialog element into which you must enter data according to a particular syntax or structure. This includes the following:
Elements where you must enter a command, or command line-type information in the element.
Elements where the data is part of a database.

Normal text rules.
Verb: Enter.
Noun: Field.
Use the guilabel tag for the field name.
Enter a command in the Command Line entry field.

Do not use the term field to refer to an element in a dialog, unless that element is a field as defined above. Instead, refer to the element by control type, that is, text box, spin box, drop-down combination box, and so on.

You can add a qualifier to the term field to help the reader to understand the nature of the field. For example, you might refer to a field as a data field or as an entry field. This can be useful particularly if the field does not have a label.

varlistentry.term:
file content sniffer [System administration documentation]
file content sniffer [System administration documentation], GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A file content sniffer specifies a pattern to search for in a file, and associates the pattern with a MIME type. If a match for the pattern is found, the MIME type associated with the pattern is the MIME type of the file.
File content sniffers are specified in the file /usr/gnome/etc/gnome-vfs-mime-magic.

varlistentry.term:
filename
filename, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: The name of a file as stored in a directory on a disk.
The term filename can also represent a real filename. For example, when you give an example of a filename in a command.
Prose tag rules for the term filename.
Use the filename tag for filenames.
Use the replaceable tag on the term filename when filename represents any filename. See Example 2 below.
Use the Image filename text box to specify the filename of the image.

Choose
Files
filename to view the file, where filename is the name of the file.

varlistentry.term: flag flag, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: In an email client application, a feature that you can add to a message to specify an action for the message, and a due date and due time for the action. In Evolution, flags are displayed at the top of messages.
Use flags to remind yourself to follow up on issues that arise from your messages.
Do not use follow-up flag as a synonym for flag.

varlistentry.term:
flip
flip, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: To switch to another workspace or viewport on screen by moving a window or the mouse pointer to the edge of the screen.
Use the spin box to specify the delay in milliseconds from the time you touch the edge of the screen with the mouse pointer to when you flip to another workspace or viewport.
Use this term specifically to describe the act of flipping and not as a synonym for switch.

varlistentry.term:
focus
focus, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: The state in which an interface component can receive both keyboard input and mouse input.
Use the following verbs with focus:

listitem.para: Give focus.
Receive focus.
Have focus.

entry.para: You can configure how to switch focus from one window to another.

Only one window or control can have focus at any one time. The window that has focus is normally indicated by a highlighted label or titlebar. Objects within a focused window, such as dialog elements, tabbed sections, and buttons, can also have focus. The user or application can set the focus.

varlistentry.term: folderbar folderbar, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: The bar at the top of a File Roller window that enables you to navigate through folders within an archive.
File Roller displays the folderbar only in folder view.

varlistentry.term:
font selector dialog
font selector dialog, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A dialog that you use to select a font. When you click on a font selector button, the font selector dialog is displayed.
Click on the font selector button to display the font selector dialog.
Font selector dialog is a generic term for the dialog that is displayed when you click on a font selector button. Do not use this term to refer to the Font Selector application.

varlistentry.term:
GConf [System administration documentation]
GConf [System administration documentation], GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: The user preference management system for the GNOME Desktop. GConf contains the following components:

listitem.para: A repository of user preferences
A daemon
A command line tool

entry.para: All GNOME Desktop applications store preferences in the GConf repository.
Initial capitals for GC, normal text rules for onf.
Use the application tag for the term GConf.
GConf makes user preferences more manageable for system administrators.
Do not use Gconf, gconf, or any other term.

varlistentry.term:
GConf configuration source [System administration documentation]
GConf configuration source [System administration documentation], GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A storage location in the GConf repository.
Use the application tag for the term GConf.
Use prose tag rules for the term configuration source.
GConf reads the configuration sources in the order specified in the GConf path file.
You can shorten GConf configuration source to configuration source when you are clearly referring to the GConf configuration source.

varlistentry.term:
GConf path file [System administration documentation]
GConf path file [System administration documentation], GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: The file that lists the configuration sources for GConf to search, and the order in which to search the configuration sources.
Use the application tag for the term GConf.
Use prose tag rules for the term path file.
Each user has a GConf path file.
You can shorten GConf path file to path file when you are clearly referring to the GConf path file.

varlistentry.term:
GConf preference key [System administration documentation]
GConf preference key [System administration documentation], GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: An element in the GConf repository that corresponds to a preference.
Use the application tag for the term GConf.
Use prose tag rules for the term preference key.
Use the literal tag for the name of a preference key.
The /apps/gnome-session/options/show_splash_screen preference key corresponds to the Show splash screen on login option in the Sessions preference tool.
You can shorten GConf preference key to preference key when you are clearly referring to the GConf preference key.

varlistentry.term:
GConf repository [System administration documentation]
GConf repository [System administration documentation], GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A collection of key-value pairs, in a hierarchical file system structure, that represent user preferences.
Use the application tag for the term GConf.
Use prose tag rules for the term repository.
The GConf repository is structured as a simple hierarchical file system.
You can shorten GConf repository to repository when you are clearly referring to the GConf repository.

varlistentry.term:
GConf schema [System administration documentation]
GConf schema [System administration documentation], GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A collective term for a GConf schema key and a GConf schema object.
Typically, GConf schemas are stored in the default configuration source.
You can shorten GConf schema to schema when you are clearly referring to the GConf schema.

varlistentry.term:
GConf schema definition file [System administration documentation]
GConf schema definition file [System administration documentation], GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A file that lists the keys in a particular application and defines the characteristics of the keys. Typically, schema definition files have a .schemas filename extension.
Use the filename tag for the name of a schema definition file.
Schemas are generated from schema definition files.
You can shorten GConf schema definition file to schema definition file when you are clearly referring to the GConf schema definition file.

varlistentry.term:
GConf schema key [System administration documentation]
GConf schema key [System administration documentation], GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A key that stores a schema object for a preference key.
The /schemas/desktop/gnome/interface/font_name key is a schema key for the /desktop/gnome/interface/font_name preference key.
You can shorten GConf schema key to schema key when you are clearly referring to the GConf schema key.

varlistentry.term:
GConf schema object [System administration documentation]
GConf schema object [System administration documentation], GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: An element in a configuration source that contains information about a preference key. The schema object contains information such as a suggested value for the preference key, and documentation on the preference key.
If the value of the schema key is a schema object, return the suggested value from the schema object.
You can shorten GConf schema object to schema object when you are clearly referring to the GConf schema object.

varlistentry.term:
GNOME
GNOME, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: All uppercase letters at all times.
The GNOME Desktop offers many user-configurable features.
If you refer to an interface element that has Gnome in title capitalization, you still write the term in all uppercase letters.

varlistentry.term: GNOME Desktop GNOME Desktop, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: The totality of all windows, panels, and workspaces.
All uppercase letters for GNOME. Initial uppercase letter for the term Desktop.
Always use GNOME in this context, that is, do not use Desktop as a shortened form of GNOME Desktop.
You can include the version number of GNOME after the word GNOME.
Use GNOME Desktop in the user interface, in Help, in documentation body text, for marketing purposes, book titles, and references to the product.
See also desktop, desktop background, desktop environment.

varlistentry.term:
GNOME footprint
terms to avoid GNOME footprint

listitem.para: Do not use this term. When you want to refer to the stylized footprint logo, use GNOME logo. When you want to refer to the footprint icon that represents the Main Menu, use Main Menu button.

varlistentry.term:
group box
group box, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A box, in a dialog, that groups a set of related dialog elements.

Normal text rules.
Verb: None.
Noun: Group.
Prose tag rules for the term group.
Use the guilabel tag for group box names.
To enable autohide, select the Autohide option in the Hiding group.
If you need to be very clear about the location of a dialog element, you can also identify the group that the element resides in.

varlistentry.term:
handle, noun
handle, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A vertical bar that you use to move an object. For example, in gedit the menubar and toolbar have a handle on the left side. You can use this handle to move the menubar and toolbar to a different location in the GNOME Desktop.
Select this option to add a handle to the menubar. Grab the handle and drag the menubar to any location in the GNOME Desktop.
The vertical bar at the left side of some applets is a handle. You can use the bar to move the applet. Therefore, refer to the bar as a handle.

varlistentry.term:
handle, verb
terms to avoid handle

listitem.para: Do not use this term. Use another verb appropriate to the context, for example, process, manage, and so on.

varlistentry.term:
hover
terms to avoid hover

listitem.para: Do not use this term. Use the term point to.

varlistentry.term:
icon selector dialog
icon selector dialog, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A dialog that you use to select an icon. When you click on an icon selector button the icon selector dialog is displayed.
Click on the Normal tile icon selector button to display the icon selector dialog.
Icon selector dialog is a generic term for the dialog that is displayed when you click on an icon selector button.

varlistentry.term:
keymap
keymap, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A group of shortcuts. A keymap can contain shortcuts that are active throughout the GNOME Desktop, or shortcuts that are only active for a particular interface item.
You can use the Sawfish preference tool to view, add, edit, or delete shortcuts from keymaps.

varlistentry.term:
launcher
launcher, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: An item that starts an application or executes a command when you click on the item. You can find launchers in the following places in the GNOME Desktop:

listitem.para: Panels: On panels, launchers are represented by icons.
Menus: On menus, launchers are represented by menu items.
Desktop: On the desktop, launchers are represented by icons.

entry.para: The properties of a launcher include the name of the launcher, the icon that represents the launcher, and how the launcher runs.

varlistentry.term:
layer
layer, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: The GNOME Desktop is structured as a sequence of layers. Each user interface item, such as a window or a panel, is a member of a layer. Each layer has a layer number. A layer number is an integer that represents the position of a layer in the stacking order. Items with a higher layer number always appear above items with a lower layer number. For example, a panel in layer four always appears above a window in layer zero.
Select this option to bring windows to the top of the stacking order within the layer when they are unshaded.

varlistentry.term:
list box
list box, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A dialog element that you use to select one of several items. A list box has no drop-down feature.

Normal text rules.
Verb: Select or choose, depending on the function that the list box fulfills.
Noun: List box.
Prose tag rules for the term list box.
Use the guilabel tag for the list box name.
Select the keymaps you require from the Keymaps list box.

varlistentry.term:
location bar
location bar, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A bar that contains elements whose primary function is to enable you to change your location. For example, the location bar on a Nautilus window contains a Location field, zoom buttons, and a View as drop-down list.
To view a website or an FTP site, type the URL for the site in the field on the location bar, then press Return.
A fixed menu that you can open from various places in the GNOME Desktop, including shortcut keys and the Main Menu button.
To open the Main Menu, click on the Main Menu button.

varlistentry.term:
Main Menu button
Main Menu button, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A button that opens the Main Menu. The default appearance of the Main Menu button in panels and menus is a stylized footprint icon.
Title capitalization for the term Main Menu, all lowercase letters for the term button.
Use the guibutton tag on the term Main Menu.
Prose tag rules for the term button.
To open the Main Menu, click on the Main Menu button.

varlistentry.term:
maximize
maximize, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: To enlarge a window to fill the GNOME Desktop to the maximum area allowed, constrained by other GNOME Desktop elements such as panels. You can maximize windows vertically, horizontally, or both.

listitem.para: Verb: Prose tag rules.
Button: Use the guibutton tag for the Maximize button.

entry.para: To maximize a window, click on the Maximize button.
Do not use fill as a synonym for maximize.

varlistentry.term:
menubar
menubar, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: The bar at the top of a window that contains the menus for an application.
The menubar on the Calculator window contains the Calculator, Edit, and Help menus.
Spell as one word, do not use menu bar.

varlistentry.term:
menu item
menu item, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: An item that you can choose from a menu.
Prose tag rules for the term menu item.
Use the menuitem tag when you refer to a menu item name.
The File menu contains the Print menu item.
If necessary, use item in a menu to avoid any ambiguity.

varlistentry.term:
menu item popup menu
menu item popup menu, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A popup menu that opens when you right-click on a launcher in a menu. The menu item popup menu contains commands such as the following:

To open the menu item popup menu for Calculator, choose
Applications Accessories , then right-click on Calculator.

varlistentry.term:
Menu Panel
Menu Panel, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: The panel that stretches the full width of the top edge of the GNOME Desktop. The Menu Panel includes textual rather than graphical menus.
Unlike other types of panel, you can only have one Menu Panel at a time on the GNOME Desktop.

varlistentry.term:
MIME information file [System administration documentation]
MIME information file [System administration documentation], GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A MIME information file is a text file that associates MIME types with filename extensions and filename patterns. MIME information files have a .mime file extension.
In MIME information files, the filename pattern to search for is written as a regular expression.

varlistentry.term:
MIME keys file [System administration documentation]
MIME keys file [System administration documentation], GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A MIME keys file provides information about a MIME type that is used in the user interface. For example, the MIME keys file specifies an icon to represent files of that MIME type. MIME keys files have a .keys file extension.
You must indent the keys in a MIME keys file with a tab character (\t).

varlistentry.term:
MIME type registry [System administration documentation]
MIME type registry [System administration documentation], GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: The MIME type registry is a location that contains text files that register MIME types for the GNOME Desktop.
The MIME type registry for the GNOME Desktop is located in the /usr/gnome/share/mime-info directory.

varlistentry.term:
minimize
minimize, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para:
To remove a window from the display without closing the window. You can restore a minimized window to your display in the following ways:
Click on the button that represents the window on the Window List applet.
Click on the window list icon at the extreme right of the Menu Panel, then select the window name from the window list.
Use shortcut keys to switch between windows. To restore a window, release the keys.

listitem.para: Verb: Prose tag rules.
Button: Use the guibutton tag for the Minimize button.

entry.para: To minimize a window, click on the Minimize button.

varlistentry.term:
native viewport
native viewport, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: The viewport where a minimized window was displayed before it was minimized.
If this option is not selected, minimized windows restore to their native viewport.

varlistentry.term:
native workspace
native workspace, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: The workspace where a minimized window was displayed before it was minimized.
If this option is not selected, minimized windows restore to their native workspace.

varlistentry.term:
option
option, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A function or parameter that you can select in a dialog. An option can be either on or off. An option is usually represented by a check box.
Prose tag rules for the term option.
Use the guilabel tag for the name of the option.
Select the Create monochrome image option to capture a black-and-white screenshot.

varlistentry.term:
panel
panel, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: An area on the GNOME Desktop from which you can run applications and applets.

The following rules apply:
When the panel is a specific user interface component, then write the term with an initial uppercase letter. For example, Menu Panel.
When the panel is a type of user interface component, then write the term according to normal text rules.
Panels are areas on the GNOME Desktop from which you can access all of your system applications and menus.

varlistentry.term:
panel object
panel object, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: An object that resides on a panel.

You can move panel objects in the following ways:
From one location to another within a panel.
From one panel to another panel.
You can also move objects between panels and drawers.
Click on the Run panel object.

You can shorten panel object to object where the meaning is not ambiguous. Also, you do not always need to add the modifier panel object when you write about launchers, menus, applets, and drawers. You can write "click on the Terminal launcher", and so on. However, when you write about other panel objects, such as the Log Out button and the Lock button, specify that the item is a panel object. The following objects can reside on panels:
Launchers
Menus
Applets
Drawers
Other panel objects, such as the Log Out button and the Lock button

varlistentry.term:
panel object popup menu
panel object popup menu, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para:
The menu that appears when you right-click on a panel object. Items that typically appear on panel object popup menus include:
Properties
Help
Remove From Panel
Move
Right-click on a launcher to open the panel object popup menu.

varlistentry.term:
panel popup menu
panel popup menu, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: The menu that appears when you right-click on a vacant space on a panel. The panel popup menu includes menu items such as Add to Panel, Delete This Panel, New Panel, and so on.
Right-click on a vacant space on a panel to open the panel popup menu.

varlistentry.term:
pattern mask [System administration documentation]
pattern mask [System administration documentation], GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A pattern mask is a series of hexadecimal characters in a file content sniffer. The pattern mask identifies bits in the pattern to ignore when searching for a pattern in a file.
Use a pattern mask to specify bits to ignore in a search pattern.

varlistentry.term:
persistent window group
persistent window group, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A window group that remains in your list of window groups even after you end and restart a session.
You can create a persistent window group, and then assign windows to be part of the group.

varlistentry.term:
popup menu
popup menu, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A menu that opens when you right-click or middle-click on an object. A popup menu usually provides commands that are relevant to the object that you click on.
If you right-click on a panel, a popup menu opens.

varlistentry.term:
preference tool
preference tool, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A utility that you can use to specify your GNOME Desktop preferences. For example, you can use the Background preference tool to specify a color for the desktop background. Also, you can use the Mouse preference tool to change your mouse buttons from right-handed to left-handed.
Normal text rules for the term preference tool. Use title capitalization for the names of preference tools.
Use the application tag for the names of preference tools.
You can use the Theme preferences tool to select a theme for the GNOME Desktop.
If there is a possibility that the term preference tool might be confusing in a particular context, use the more specific term GNOME Desktop preference tool.

varlistentry.term:
radio button
radio button, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A dialog element that you use to select one of several mutually exclusive options.

Normal text rules.
Verb: Use select or choose, depending on the function of the radio button.
Noun: Option.
Use the guilabel tag for radio button names.
Select the Scale image option to scale the background image to fit the panel background.
Avoid using the term radio button in your documentation. Use the term option instead.

varlistentry.term:
raise
raise, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: To bring a window to the top of the stacking order within a layer.
Right-click on the titlebar to raise the window.

varlistentry.term: Remote Desktop Remote Desktop, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A feature that enables you to access the Desktop of another user from your system.
Use the Remote Desktop feature to view or control the Desktop of another user from your Desktop.
To avoid confusion with the term desktop, use title capitalization for this term.
See also desktop, desktop background, desktop environment, GNOME Desktop.

varlistentry.term:
restore
restore, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: To restore a minimized or maximized window to the dimensions that the window had before you minimized or maximized the window.
To restore a maximized window, click on the Maximize button. To restore a minimized window, click on the button for the window in the Window List applet.

Do not use the following terms as synonyms for restore:
Uniconify
Unmaximize

varlistentry.term: roll down roll down, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: To restore a rolled-up window to the original dimensions of the window.
To roll down a window, double-click on the titlebar.
Do not use the term unshade as a synonym for roll down.

varlistentry.term: roll up roll up, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: To reduce a window so that the body of the window moves into the titlebar. When you roll up a window, only the titlebar of the window is visible.
To roll up a window, double-click on the titlebar.
Do not use the term shade as a synonym for roll up.

varlistentry.term:
Root menu
Root menu, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A menu that you can use to navigate between windows and workspaces.
Initial uppercase letter for the term Root, all lowercase letters in the term menu.
Use the guimenu tag for the term Root.
To open the Root menu, middle-click on the desktop.

varlistentry.term:
scrollbar
scrollbar, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A scrollbar is a navigation bar that enables you to move through the contents of a window or list box. A scrollbar appears at the side or bottom of a window or list box. A scrollbar contains an arrow at both ends. You click on the arrows to move through a window or list box. A scrollbar also contains a box that you drag to move through a window or list box.
Use the scrollbar to scroll through the contents of the window.

varlistentry.term: searchbar searchbar, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: The bar near the top of an Evolution window that you can use to search your messages and other items.
You can use the searchbar to search the contents of the messages in your message list.

varlistentry.term:
session
session, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: The current GNOME Desktop session that you are using.

Use the following terms in relation to session:
Log in to a session. Do not use log on to a session.
Log outof a session. Do not use log off from a session.
Click on the Log Out button to log out of a GNOME Desktop session.
You log in to a session. You do not log in to your workstation, system, or workspace.

varlistentry.term: setting setting, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A value for an adjustable characteristic of a user interface component. Interactive components such as applications and applets, and objects such as files and folders, have associated controls that you can use to modify adjustable characteristics for the component. For example, the Workspace Switcher Preferences dialog contains a Number of workspaces spin box that you can use to specify the number of workspaces on the GNOME Desktop. A setting is the value to which you set the control. For example, the setting of the Number of workspaces spin box might be 4.
The session manager saves your fonts, background, and mouse settings.
The window frame setting for a theme determines the appearance of the frames around windows.
Setting is not a synonym for preference or property.

varlistentry.term:
shade
shade, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: To reduce a window so that only the titlebar is visible.
To shade a window, double-click on the titlebar.

varlistentry.term:
shutdown, noun, adjective
shutdown, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: The process of shutting down all processes running on a computer.
The shutdown procedure takes approximately two minutes.
Do not use shutdown as a verb.

varlistentry.term:
shut down, verb
shut down, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: To stop all processes running on a computer.
The Log Out dialog enables you to shut down or reboot your computer.
Do not use shut down as a noun or adjective.

varlistentry.term:
side pane
side pane, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: The pane on the left side of a Nautilus window. The side pane displays information about the current file or folder. The side pane also enables you to navigate through your files.
To add a note, click on the Notes tab in the side pane.

varlistentry.term:
slider
slider, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A control that you use to set a value in a continuous range of values.

Normal text rules.
Verb Phrase: Use the slider_name slider to specify.
Noun: Slider.
Use the slider to specify the volume level.

varlistentry.term:
spin box
spin box, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A dialog element that allows you to either type a numeric value, or scroll through all possible values for the item. A spin box is similar to a text box with up and down arrows.

Normal text rules.
Verb: Use the spin_box_name spin box to specify.
Noun: Spin box.
Prose tag rules for the term spin box.
Use the guilabel tag for the spin box name.
Use the Number of workspaces spin box to specify the number of workspaces on the GNOME Desktop.

varlistentry.term:
stacking order
stacking order, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para:
The order in which windows are stacked on top of one another on your screen. The position of a window in the stacking order depends on:
The layer of which the window is a member.
The position of the window in the order of windows within the layer.
Select this option to bring windows to the top of the stacking order within the layer when they are unshaded.

varlistentry.term:
staggered
staggered, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: Use this term to describe the display of a new window or dialog slightly lower and to the right of the previous window or dialog.
Subsequent dialogs are staggered from the previous dialog.

varlistentry.term:
statusbar
statusbar, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: The bar at the bottom of a window that provides information about the current state of what you are viewing in the window. The statusbar also provides any other contextual information.
The Nautilus statusbar displays status information on the selected file or folder.
Spell as one word, do not use status bar.

varlistentry.term:
stick
stick, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: If a window is set to stick, then the window appears in all workspaces that you view. You can use the Window Menu to switch the stick setting on and off.
Prose tag rules for the term stick.
Use the guimenuitem tag when you refer to menu items.
To set a window to stick, open the Window Menu, then choose Put on All Workspaces.
Do not use the term sticky.

varlistentry.term:
submenu
submenu, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A menu that resides in another menu.
Prose tag rules for the term submenu.
Use the guisubmenu tag for the name of a submenu.

When you add an executable file to this folder, the file is added to the
File Scripts submenu.

varlistentry.term:
tab
tab, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: The part of a tabbed section that you click on to view the tabbed section.

Normal text rules.
Verb Phrase: Click on.
Noun: Tab.
Prose tag rules for the term tab. Use the guilabel tag for tab names.
To modify panel size, position, and hiding properties, click on the Panel tab.

varlistentry.term:
tabbed pane
tabbed pane, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A functional area in the Nautilus side pane. To open a tabbed pane, click on a tab in the side pane.
Normal text rules for the term tabbed pane. Use title capitalization for the name of a tabbed pane.
Prose tag rules for the term tabbed pane.
Use the guilabel tag for the name of a tabbed pane.
Type the note in the Notes tabbed pane.

varlistentry.term:
tabbed section
tabbed section, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A tabbed section is one of multiple logical sections that appear on a dialog. To activate a tabbed section, click on the tab on the tabbed section.

Normal text rules.
Verb: None.
Noun: Tabbed section.
Prose tag rules for the term tabbed section.
Use the guilabel tag for the name of the tabbed section.
You can use the Advanced tabbed section to add translations of the comment.

varlistentry.term:
table
table, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: An element in a dialog or window that includes rows, columns, and column headings.
Prose tag rules for the term table.
Use the guilabel tag for the table name.
Enter the details of the translation in the Name/Comment translations table.

varlistentry.term:
terminal
terminal, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A window with a command line.
Use the application tag for the Terminal application.
Select this option to run the application or command in a terminal.

varlistentry.term:
text box
text box, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A dialog element where you type text.

Normal text rules.
Verb Phrase: Use the text box to specify.
Noun: Text box.
Prose tag rules for the term text box.
Use the guilabel tag for the text box name.
Use the Tooltip/Name text box to specify a name for the drawer.
Spell as two words, do not use textbox.

varlistentry.term:
theme
theme, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A group of coordinated settings that specify how a part of your interface appears. For example, you can select a default theme for dialog elements.
Select a theme from the Available Themes list box.

varlistentry.term:
titlebar
titlebar, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A bar that appears at the top edge of a window. Typically a titlebar contains the title of the window.
Select the Capture WM decorations when grabbing a window option to include the titlebar and border of a window in a screenshot.
Spell as one word, do not use title bar.

varlistentry.term:
toolbar
toolbar, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A bar that appears below the menubar and contains buttons for the most commonly-used commands.

The Eye of GNOME toolbar contains the following buttons:
Open
Close
Spell as one word, do not use tool bar.

varlistentry.term:
tree
tree, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A tree is a user interface control that contains sections that you can expand and collapse. A tree usually represents a hierarchical structure. The sections of the tree that you can expand and collapse are indicated by, for example, + and - signs.
To open an item in a tree, click on the + (plus) sign next to the item.

varlistentry.term:
uniconify
terms to avoid uniconify

listitem.para: Do not use this term. Use the term restore.

varlistentry.term:
unmaximize
terms to avoid unmaximize

listitem.para: Do not use this term. Use the term restore.

varlistentry.term:
unshade
unshade, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: To restore a shaded window to the unshaded dimensions of the window.
To unshade a window, double-click on the titlebar.

varlistentry.term:
username
username, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A combination of letters and numbers that identifies a user to the system.
The term username can also represent a real username. For example, when you give an example of a username in a command.
Use the replaceable tag for username when you give an example of a username.
The login screen provides fields for you to enter your username and password.
To log in to a remote system, use the following command: rlogin -l username systemname

varlistentry.term:
vfolder [System administration documentation]
vfolder [System administration documentation], GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A virtual representation of items that reside in a physical location or physical locations on your system. For example, a vfolder might represent the contents of several directories. In terms of menus, a vfolder is a representation, in a menu, of items that might be physically located in several directories.
In terms of menus in the GNOME Desktop, a vfolder is a representation, in a menu, of items that might be physically located in several directories.
Do not use Vfolder, vFolder, or any other term.
Use an initial capital for Vfolder when the term appears at the start of a sentence.

varlistentry.term:
viewport
viewport, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: To move a window or dialog from one workspace to another, middle-click on the viewport for the window or dialog.

varlistentry.term:
view pane
view pane, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: The pane on the right side of a Nautilus window. Nautilus displays your files and folders in the view pane. When you access a web page, Nautilus displays the page in the view pane.
Display in the view pane the item that you want to bookmark.

varlistentry.term:
virtual desktop
terms to avoid virtual desktop

listitem.para: Do not use this term. Use the term workspace.

varlistentry.term: virtual folder virtual folder, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A representation, as a folder, of messages that might reside in more than one folder. Virtual folders enable you to view messages that are located in several folders, as if the messages are in one folder.
Use virtual folders to organize messages that might belong in more than one folder.
Do not use vfolder as a synonym for an Evolution virtual folder.

varlistentry.term:
wallpaper
terms to avoid wallpaper

listitem.para: Do not use this term. Use the term desktop background.

varlistentry.term:
widget
terms to avoid widget

listitem.para: Do not use this term in user documentation. Use the term control.

varlistentry.term:
window
window, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A rectangular frame that displays a particular application.
Use the guilabel tag for the name of a window.
You can grab the titlebar of a window, then drag the window to a new location.

varlistentry.term:
window frame
window frame, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: The titlebar and border that appears around windows and dialogs.
Use the Theme preference tool to change the theme of your window frames.

varlistentry.term:
window group (1)
window group (1), GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A group of windows. You can use the Sawfish preference tool to configure the GNOME Desktop so that when you minimize one member of the window group, the other windows in the group are also minimized.
Brackets around the title of a window indicate that the window is a member of a window group.
You can shorten window group to group where there is no ambiguity.

varlistentry.term:
window group (2)
window group (2), GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A group of windows in the Window List applet.
To open a list of the members of a window group, click on the button that represents the window group.
You can shorten window group to group where there is no ambiguity.
The Window List window group bears no relation to the Sawfish window group.

varlistentry.term:
window list
window list, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para:
A list of the windows that are open on your screen. To view your window list, perform one of the following actions:
Add the Window List applet to a panel. The Window List applet is an iconic display of your windows. The buttons in your Window List applet represent your windows.
Open the Root menu, then choose Windows.
Click on the window list icon at the extreme right of the Menu Panel.
Use the arrow keys to cycle through the window list.

varlistentry.term:
window list icon
window list icon, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: The icon at the extreme right of the Menu Panel, which you click on to display a list of your open windows.
To give focus to a window, click on the window list icon, then select the window.
A menu of actions that you can perform on a window. For example, the Metacity Window Menu includes the following menu items: Close, Minimize, Maximize, Shade.
Use the Window Menu to perform actions on your windows.

varlistentry.term:
window name
window name, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: The name of a window, which is displayed in the titlebar.
On the Window List applet, square brackets around the window name indicate that the window is minimized.
Do not use window title as a synonym for window name.

varlistentry.term:
workspace
workspace, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A discrete area in which you can work. You can have many workspaces in the GNOME Desktop, and you can switch from one workspace to another. Each workspace can contain different windows or processes. You can only work in one workspace at any time.
Use the Number of workspaces spin box to specify the number of workspaces you require.
Do not use virtual desktop as a synonym for workspace.

varlistentry.term:
workspace list
workspace list, GNOME Desktop term

entry.para: A list of the workspaces that are in your session. Workspace Switcher displays your workspace list.
Workspace Switcher adds new workspaces to the end of the workspace list.

sect1.title: Buttons in the GNOME Desktop
sect1.para: This section lists the terms to use when you refer to buttons in the GNOME Desktop.

varlistentry.term:
... button
... button, buttons term

entry.para: A button that you click on to perform an action. This action is usually to display a list of options from which you can choose.

Normal text rules.
Verb Phrase: Click on.
Noun: Button. Give directions to the button.
To choose a signal for the window to respond to, click on the button to the right of the Signal field.

varlistentry.term:
arrow button
arrow button, buttons term

entry.para: A button that you click on to display more information. Arrow buttons appear in the following locations:

listitem.para: Drop-down combination boxes
Drop down lists
List boxes
Scrollbars, at both ends
Spin boxes

entry.para:
Normal text rules.
Verb Phrase: Click on.
Noun: Arrow button.
To scroll through the list, click on the arrow buttons.
Refer to the buttons on a spin box as arrow buttons. If an arrow button has a function, you can name the button by the function. For example, the History button in the Command Line applet.

varlistentry.term:
color selector button
color selector button, buttons term

entry.para: A button that you use to choose a color. When you click on a color selector button the color selector dialog is displayed.
Normal text rules for the term color selector button. Standard capitalization rules for specific color selector button names.

listitem.para: Verb Phrase: Click on.
Noun: Button, color selector button. Use the more verbose form where you need to clarify that you are referring to a color selector button.

entry.para: Use the guibutton tag with specific color selector button names.
To choose a background color for the panel, click on the Color to use button.

varlistentry.term:
command button
command button, buttons term

entry.para: A button that you use to start an action. Command buttons are always rectangular in shape. Command buttons always have a text label, but the label can also include a graphic.
Title capitalization for the command button name.

listitem.para: Verb: Click when the button represents a frequently-used command such as OK. Click on when the button represents a GNOME-specific or little-known command.
Noun: None. You usually do not need to use a noun to refer to a command button. For example, click OK. If you must use a noun, use button.

entry.para: Use the guibutton tag for the command button name.
To save your changes and close the dialog, click Close.
To delete a translation of a launcher, select the translation then click on the Remove button.

varlistentry.term:
font selector button
font selector button, buttons term

entry.para: A button that you use to choose a font. When you click on a font selector button the font selector dialog is displayed.

Normal text rules.
Verb Phrase: Click on.
Noun: Button, font selector button. Use the more verbose form where you need to clarify that you are referring to a font selector button.
If you refer to a specific font selector button name, use the guibutton tag for the button name.
To choose a font in which to display your gedit documents, click on the Default Font button.
To choose a font to in which to display the pronunciation of a word, click on the Pronunciation font selector button.

varlistentry.term:
hide button
hide button, buttons term

entry.para: A button that enables you to hide a panel or drawer. You can also use hide buttons to show hidden panels. Hide buttons appear at either end of panels and at one end of open drawers.

Normal text rules.
Verb Phrase: Click on.
Noun: Hide button.
Select the Show hide buttons option to display hide buttons on your panels.

varlistentry.term:
icon selector button
icon selector button, buttons term

entry.para: A button that you use to choose an icon. When you click on an icon selector button, the icon selector dialog is displayed.
If you refer to a specific icon selector button name, use the guibutton tag for the button name.

Normal text rules.
Verb Phrase: Click on.
Noun: Button, icon selector button. Use the more verbose form where you need to clarify that you are referring to an icon selector button.
To choose an icon to represent the application, click on the Icon button.
To choose an icon to represent the keyboard map, click on the icon selector button at the right side of the dialog.

varlistentry.term:
Normal Size button
Normal Size button, buttons term

entry.para: A button that enables you to change the size of items in a view pane to the normal size. The Normal Size button displays "100%", and appears in the location bar on a Nautilus window.
Title capitalization for the term Normal Size, all lowercase letters for the term button.
Use the guibutton tag for the term Normal Size.
To restore the size of items in a view to normal size, click on the Normal Size button.

varlistentry.term:
toggle button
toggle button, buttons term

entry.para: A button that you use to switch between two states.

listitem.para: Verb: Select.
Noun: Option.

entry.para: Use the guibutton tag with the toggle button name.
To show grid lines, select the Visible option.

varlistentry.term:
toolbar button
toolbar button, buttons term

entry.para: A button in an application toolbar. Toolbar buttons are usually shortcuts to functionality that is available in the menus of the application.

Normal text rules for the term button.
Verb Phrase: Click button_name on the toolbar, click on the button_name button.
Noun: Button.
Use the guibutton tag for the toolbar button name.
To refresh the contents of the view pane, click on the Reload button.

varlistentry.term:
window frame button
window frame button, buttons term

entry.para:
One of the following buttons that reside in a window frame:
Window Menu button
Minimize button
Maximize button
Close Window button
Normal text rules for the term button.

listitem.para: Verb Phrase: Click on.
Noun: Button.

entry.para: Use the guibutton tag for the window frame button name.
To open the Window Menu, click on the Window Menu button.

varlistentry.term:
window list button
window list button, buttons term

entry.para: A button that represents a window in the Window List applet.

listitem.para: Verb Phrase: Click on.
Noun: Window list button.

entry.para: To restore a window, click on the window list button for the window in the Window List applet.

varlistentry.term:
Zoom In button
Zoom In button, buttons term

entry.para: A button that enables you to increase the size of items in a view pane. The Zoom In button displays a plus sign, and appears in the location bar on a Nautilus window.
Title capitalization for the term Zoom In, all lowercase letters for the term button.
Use the guibutton tag for the term Zoom In.
To increase the size of items in a view, click on the Zoom In button.

varlistentry.term:
Zoom Out button
Zoom Out button, buttons term

entry.para: A button that enables you to reduce the size of items in a view pane. The Zoom Out button displays a minus sign, and appears in the location bar on a Nautilus window.
Title capitalization for the term Zoom Out, all lowercase letters for the term button.
Use the guibutton tag for the term Zoom Out.
To reduce the size of items in a view, click on the Zoom Out button.

sect1.title: User Actions
sect1.para: This section defines a list of user actions in the GNOME Desktop.

varlistentry.term:
activate [Accessibility documentation]
activate [Accessibility documentation], user actions term

entry.para: Use this verb to describe the action of clicking on a user interface control, such as a button, when it is not appropriate to use the verb click. For example, use this verb if you are writing instructions for users who are unable to use a mouse.
Activate the applet control that has focus, if applicable.

varlistentry.term:
choose
choose, user actions term

entry.para: To pick a course of action or assign a course of action.

Choose
Applications Accessories Calculator to start the Calculator application.
On the Run Application dialog, use the drop-down combination box to choose an application to run.

varlistentry.term:
click on, click
click on, click, user actions terms

entry.para: Press and release the left mouse button on an item once.

You can differentiate between click on and click as follows:
Click on: Use this verb when you refer to most interactive elements in the GNOME Desktop, such as:
GNOME-specific buttons.
Buttons that represent commands that are not frequently used.
All interactive elements other than buttons, such as column headings.
Click: Use this verb when you refer to frequently-used command buttons, for example:
OK
Cancel
Save
Revert
Try
Apply
Close
Help
Yes
No
Find
Replace
Browse
To hide a panel, click on one of the hide buttons.

varlistentry.term:
click-and-hold
click-and-hold, user actions term

entry.para: Press and hold the left mouse button on an item.
Click-and-hold the left mouse button to initiate the capture area.

varlistentry.term:
close
close, user actions term

entry.para: To remove a window, dialog, or user interface component from the GNOME Desktop. Use in conjunction with display and open.

To close a window, choose
File Close .
Click Cancel to close the dialog.
Do not use quit in this context.

varlistentry.term:
collapse
collapse, user actions term

entry.para: To close an open item in a tree structure. The Tree tabbed pane in the Nautilus file manager is a tree structure. To collapse a folder in the Tree tabbed pane, click on the arrow next to the folder.
You can expand and collapse the folders in the Tree tabbed pane.

varlistentry.term:
configure
configure, user actions term

entry.para: To set up an application. To configure is typically a larger-scale activity, and usually occurs at installation time.
You can configure how PDAs connect to your computer.

varlistentry.term: customize customize, user actions term

entry.para: To modify the behavior of an application to suit individual requirements.
To customize a panel, use the Panel preference tool.

varlistentry.term:
delete
delete, user actions term

entry.para: When you delete a file or folder, the file or folder is not moved to Trash, but is deleted from your file system immediately.
To delete a panel from the GNOME Desktop, right-click on the panel that you want to delete, then choose Delete This Panel.
Do not use remove to describe the deletion of an item that you cannot add back to the GNOME Desktop.

varlistentry.term:
deselect
deselect, user actions term

entry.para: To switch off a behavioral characteristic in a dialog.
Deselect the Display tooltips option to switch off tooltips.
Do not use unselect when you refer to switching off a binary option.
Do not use deselected for a binary option that is switched off. Use unselected instead.

varlistentry.term: display display, user actions term

entry.para: Use this verb when an item is not already open somewhere in the GNOME Desktop. The item needs to be opened, added, or launched.
To display the Background Preferences dialog, right-click on the desktop, then choose Change Desktop Background.

varlistentry.term:
double-click on
double-click on, user actions term

entry.para: To press and release the left mouse button on an item twice, in rapid succession.
To start an application from the desktop, double-click on the application launcher.

varlistentry.term:
drag
drag, user actions term

entry.para: To click a mouse button on an object, hold the mouse button, and move the mouse to move the object.
Drag the launcher to the panel.
Avoid using the term drag and drop.

varlistentry.term:
duplicate
duplicate, user actions term

entry.para: To create an exact copy of an object. The new object is created in the same location as the original object.
Select the file or folder that you want to duplicate.
When you duplicate an object, the object is not copied to the clipboard.

varlistentry.term:
enter
enter, user actions term

entry.para: Use this verb to describe the following:

listitem.para: To input data into a text box or field by using a combination of typing from the keyboard, and then either pressing a key or clicking on a button.

To either:
Type data in a text box, or field.
Click on a button and select a value from a predefined list of values

entry.para: The following example describes a File text box with a Browse button beside it where you can either type the name or click Browse to select a name:
Enter a name for the output file in the File text box.
Click on the calculator buttons to enter numbers and mathematical functions.
Where possible, use specify instead of enter.

varlistentry.term:
execute
execute, user actions term

entry.para: Instruct your computer to perform a command.
Execute the following command to list the contents of the directory: ls
Execute implies that you type a command at the command line, then press Return. Execute implies a single action that the computer performs.

varlistentry.term:
exit
exit, user actions term

entry.para: To stop an application from running. Exit implies normal cessation of application activity.
If you close the last window, the application exits.

varlistentry.term:
expand
expand, user actions term

entry.para: To open a closed item in a tree structure. The Tree tabbed pane in the Nautilus file manager is a tree structure. To expand a folder in the Tree tabbed pane, click on the arrow next to the folder.
You can expand and collapse the folders in the Tree tabbed pane.

varlistentry.term:
grab
grab, user actions term

entry.para: To point to the edge of a window frame, or corner of a window, and click to take hold of the window. After a grab action you usually drag the object.
To resize the window, grab the border and drag the border to the new size.

varlistentry.term:
left-click on
left-click on, user actions term

entry.para: To press and release the left mouse button on an item once. Use this term when you want to avoid ambiguity when describing an action that also involves a middle-click or a right-click.
You can left-click on the application icons in the Window List applet to maximize and minimize application windows.

varlistentry.term:
log in, verb
log in, user actions term

entry.para: To supply a username and password to gain access to a session.
Select this option to display a splash screen when you log in.
You log in to a session, not your workstation, system, or workspace.
Use log in rather than log on.

varlistentry.term:
log out, verb
log out, user actions term

entry.para: To log out of your session or shut down your system, click on the Log Out button.
You log out of a session, not your workstation, system, or workspace.
Use log out rather than log off.

varlistentry.term:
middle-click on
middle-click on, user actions term

entry.para: To press and release the middle mouse button on an item once.
To move an applet, middle-click on the applet.

varlistentry.term:
middle-click and hold
middle-click and hold, user actions term

entry.para: To press and hold the middle mouse button on an item.
To move a panel, middle-click and hold, then drag the panel to the new location.

varlistentry.term:
modify
modify, user actions term

entry.para: To change specific parameters in an application. Use this verb to refer to making specific changes to the preferences or properties of an item.
You can modify animation preferences for your panels.

varlistentry.term:
open
open, user actions term

entry.para:
To open any user interface component. Examples of items that you can open include:
Main Menu
Applications menu
Desktop Preferences menu
Actions menu
Root menu
Desktop menu
Panel popup menu
Panel object popup menu
Right-click on a panel object to open the panel object popup menu.

varlistentry.term:
point to
point to, user actions term

entry.para: To position the pointer over a particular object or location without clicking.
When you point to the submenu icon a tooltip appears.
Use point to instead of point at.

varlistentry.term:
press
press, user actions term

entry.para: Use this verb to describe keyboard input.
Press Return to execute the command.

varlistentry.term:
press-and-hold
press-and-hold, user actions term

entry.para: To press one or more keys and hold down the keys. Typically, you press-and-hold keys while you press another key.

Press-and-hold
Ctrl Alt and continue to press Tab to switch the focus between the desktop and the panels.

varlistentry.term:
quit
quit, user actions term

entry.para: To abruptly stop an application, without necessarily completing current tasks. Quit implies a sudden or unexpected cessation of activity.
To quit the application without saving your current project, select CtrlQ.

varlistentry.term:
remove
remove, user actions term

entry.para: To remove an item or functionality that you can add back to the GNOME Desktop. When you remove an item the item is not visible to the user. When you remove functionality, the functionality is not active in the GNOME Desktop.
To remove an object from a panel, right-click on the object, then choose Remove From Panel.

row.entry: To remove a file type or a service, select the item that you want to remove, then click Remove.

entry.para: Do not use delete to describe the removal of an item that you can add back to the GNOME Desktop.

varlistentry.term:
right-click on
right-click on, user actions term

entry.para: To press and release the right mouse button on an item once.
Right-click on any part of a panel to open the panel popup menu.

varlistentry.term:
run
run, user actions term

entry.para: To change the status of an application, program, or script from continuously inactive to continuously active.
To run the Terminal application, execute the following command: gnome-terminal
Run implies a continuous flow of activity.

varlistentry.term:
select (1)
select (1), user actions term

entry.para: To identify an object as the object on which an action is to be performed. For example, the object can be text, one or more desktop launchers, a folder in the Nautilus Tree tabbed pane, and so on. When you select objects, they usually appear highlighted.
In the Menu Editor window, select the menu to which you want to add a submenu.
Do not use choose or highlight in this context.
Refer to the text that is selected as the selection, selected text, selected menu, and so on.

varlistentry.term:
select (2)
select (2), user actions term

entry.para: To pick an item that assigns a behavioral characteristic, value, or parameter from a predefined value or a predefined set of values.
Select the Display tooltips option to display tooltips when you start a GNOME session.
To change the size of the panel, select a size from the Panel size drop-down list.
Do not use select to describe more complex methods of inputting information. Use specify instead.

varlistentry.term:
selected/unselected
selected/unselected, user actions term

entry.para: Use these terms to describe the on or off state of a binary choice in a dialog.
The default state of the Display tooltips option is unselected.
Do not use deselected for a binary option that is switched off.
Do not use unselect when you refer to switching off a binary option. Use deselect instead.

varlistentry.term: show show, user actions term

entry.para: Use this verb when an item is already open somewhere in the GNOME Desktop, but hidden.
To show more options, click on the More Options button.

varlistentry.term:
specify
specify, user actions term

entry.para: Use the verb specify to describe more complex methods of inputting information. Use specify when referring to a dialog element such as a drop-down combination box, spin box, slider, text box.
Use the Minimum size spin box to specify the minimum width of the window list buttons.
Do not use specify with simpler dialog elements such as check boxes and radio buttons. Use select instead.

varlistentry.term:
start
start, user actions term

entry.para:
To start Calculator, choose
Applications Accessories Calculator .
Do not use the terms open or run in this context.

varlistentry.term:
terminate
terminate, user actions term

entry.para: To stop a system process permanently.

To terminate a process, choose
File Kill Process .
Do not use kill except where quoting the user interface.

varlistentry.term:
triple-click on
triple-click on, user actions term

entry.para: Press and release the left mouse button on an item three times in rapid succession.
To select a line at a time, triple-click on the first line that you want to select and drag the mouse to the last line that you want to select.

varlistentry.term:
type
type, user actions term

entry.para: To type text from the keyboard.
Type the content of the document in the gedit window.
Type man ghex at the command line prompt and press Return.
Type a name for the drawer in the Tooltip Name text box.

sect1.title: General Computer Terms
sect1.para: This section contains general computer terms that are not specific to the GNOME Desktop.

varlistentry.term:
3D
3D, general computer term

entry.para: Select this option to display a 3D beveled border around the full-screen view of an image.
Do not use 3-D, 3d, or any other term.

varlistentry.term:
accelerator key
terms to avoid accelerator key

listitem.para: Do not use this term. Use the term shortcut key.

varlistentry.term:
access keys
access keys, general computer term

entry.para: Keys that enable you to perform an action from the keyboard rather than using the mouse to choose a command from a menu or dialog. Each access key is identified by an underlined letter on a menu or dialog option. In some cases, you must press the Alt key in combination with the access key to perform the action.

listitem.para: Normal text rules.
Avoid using the terms access key or access keys in text instructions, if the context is clear.
Use the term access key as a qualifier for the key name.

entry.para: Use the keycap tag for key names.
Use the keycombo tag for key combinations.

To open a new file, press
Alt F . When the File menu opens, press the access key N.
Do not use mnemonic as a synonym for access key.
The Alt key on the keyboard.

Use the default shortcut keys
Alt F1 to open the Main Menu.

varlistentry.term:
a.m./p.m.
a.m./p.m., general computer term

entry.para: Use these abbreviations to refer to before and after noon.
Select 12 hour to display time in a.m./p.m. formatted time.
Do not use AM/PM, am/pm, or A.M./P.M.

varlistentry.term: antialias antialias, general computer term

entry.para: Antialiasing is an effect that is applied to the edges of characters on a screen to make the characters look smoother. If characters on a screen are not antialiased the edges of the characters might appear jagged in some cases.
Select the Best shapes option to antialias screen fonts where possible.
Do not hyphenate this term, do not use anti-alias.

varlistentry.term:
application
