application, general computer term

entry.para: A class of program that is designed to perform a specific function. For example, a calculator or web browser. An application typically has an interface that is specific to the application.
Normal text rules. Use title capitalization for application names.
Prose tag rules except when you refer to the Applications menu.
Use the application tag for application names.
The Applications menu contains several applications, including the Calculator and gedit applications.

If the application name does not follow standard capitalization rules, follow the capitalization of the application name. For example, use lowercase letters for the gedit application. When the application name begins with a lowercase letter, do not start a sentence with the name of the application.

varlistentry.term: archive, noun archive, general computer term

entry.para: A file containing one or more files in compressed format for more efficient storage and transfer.
An archive can contain many files, folders, and subfolders, usually in compressed form.
The verb that corresponds to the noun archive is compress.
Do not use zip as a synonym for archive.

varlistentry.term:
arrange
arrange, general computer term

entry.para: To organize items in an array or stack, using a specific characteristic to define the spatial relationship between the items. Essentially, arrange implies a two-dimensional or three-dimensional ordering of items. Typically, arrange applies to items in GUI-type applications, such as desktop icons, or folder icons.
You can arrange the folder icons in your window by several characteristics, such as date of creation, status, name, and so on.
Do not use sort as a synonym for arrange.

varlistentry.term:
ask
ask, general computer term

entry.para: Use this verb for a request from the system to the user when there are two or more courses of action, and the system needs to know which course of action the user wants to take.
The system asks you if you want to continue with logging out.
Do not use prompt as a synonym for ask.
The Back Space key on the keyboard.
To disable a shortcut, select the shortcut, click in the Shortcut column for the function you want to change, then press Back Space.
The Back Space key might have a left arrow on the key.

varlistentry.term:
backup, noun, adjective
backup, general computer term

entry.para: A copy of a resource made as a precaution in case of loss of the original resource.
Select this option to display backup files in the view pane.
Do not use backup as a verb.

varlistentry.term:
back up, verb
back up, general computer term

entry.para: To copy files to another location as a precaution in case of loss of the original files.
Do not use back up as a noun or adjective.

varlistentry.term: bar bar, general computer term

entry.para: A part of a window that is peripheral to the main working part of a window, and that contains functionalities and utilities to use in performing work in the main working part of the window. A bar appears as a solid object on the same visual plane as the window. The contents of a bar form a unified whole.
To show text only in your toolbars, choose Text Only from the Button Labels drop-down list.
To show the location bar in the file manager, choose ViewLocation Bar.
See also folderbar, location bar, menubar, pane, scrollbar, statusbar, toolbar.

varlistentry.term:
blank
blank, general computer term

entry.para: When no information is present in a field, refer to the field as blank.
Enter the command that you want to run in the blank field on the Run Application dialog.
Do not use empty when you refer to a field.

varlistentry.term: blind-copy blind-copy, general computer term

entry.para: To copy a message to an address, so that that address does not appear in the delivered message.
Enter any email addresses to which you want to blind-copy the message.
Hyphenate this term, do not use blind copy.
The abbreviation bcc means blind carbon copy.

varlistentry.term:
bounce keys
bounce keys, general computer term

entry.para: A keyboard accessibility feature. Use the bounce keys feature to ignore subsequent presses of the same key if they happen within the time that the user specifies.
The bounce keys control the key repeat characteristics of the keyboard.
The Caps Lock key on the keyboard.
To type in uppercase, press Caps Lock.

varlistentry.term:
command
command, general computer term

entry.para: An order from a user to the operating system to perform a service such as start an application or list the files in a directory. A command can have options, parameters, and arguments.
Prose tag rules. Use the command tag for a command or a command specification.
Use the gedit command to start the gedit application.

varlistentry.term: compress, verb compress, general computer term

listitem.para: To transform data to minimize the space required for storage or transmission.
A command used to perform this transformation.

entry.para: Prose tag rules. Use the command tag for the name of the command.

A compressed non-archive file is a file that is created when you use bzip, bzip2, gzip, lzop, or compress to compress a non-archive file. For example, file.txt.gz is created when you use gzip to compress file.txt.
The noun that corresponds to the verb compress is archive.
Do not use zip as a verb.
Use Ctrl to refer to the Control key on the keyboard.

To save the document, press
Ctrl S .

varlistentry.term:
cursor
cursor, general computer term

entry.para: A cursor is a symbol that indicates the position at which you can enter or delete text. The cursor is usually a blinking vertical bar.
Press Home to position the cursor at the start of the line.
Do not use pointer as a synonym for cursor.

varlistentry.term:
depressed
terms to avoid depressed

listitem.para: Do not use this term. Use the term pressed in.

varlistentry.term:
directory
directory, general computer term

entry.para: A special type of file that enables you to organize other files into a hierarchical structure. Only use the term directory when you make specific references to the structure of the file system.
The New Folder menu item creates a new folder on your desktop. This folder is located in the directory /.nautilus/desktop.
The down arrow key on the keyboard.

To switch to the workspace below the current workspace, press
Ctrl Alt down arrow .

varlistentry.term:
email
email, general computer term

entry.para: Electronic mail message, or an electronic mail messaging application.
Normal text rules. You can use this term as a verb, a noun, or as an adjective.
Prose tag rules for the term email. Use the email tag for email addresses.
The Inbox Monitor applet monitors your email.
Do not use e-mail, E-mail, Email or any other synonym.

varlistentry.term: emoticon emoticon, general computer term

entry.para: A short sequence of characters, or an icon, that represents a facial expression. For example, the :-) emoticon represents a smiling face. In electronic communications, emoticons portray feelings that supplement messages. Evolution includes icons that represents emoticons.
To insert an emoticon to your message, choose InsertSmiley, then choose the emoticon that you require.

varlistentry.term:
empty
empty, general computer term

entry.para: When no information is present in a text box, refer to the text box as empty.
Use the empty Name text box to specify a name for the application.
Do not use blank when referring to a text box.
The Enter key on the numeric keypad.
Use the keycap tag for Enter.
Press Enter on the numeric keypad to complete the calculation.
In Calculator the Enter key provides the same function as the equals sign (=).

Sometimes the Return key and Enter key perform the same functions. Refer to the Return key by default, and only refer to the Enter key when the user must press Enter, or when the user is likely to use the numeric keypad.
Use as an abbreviation for the Escape key on the keyboard.
To cancel the dialog, click on the Cancel button or press Esc.

varlistentry.term:
file system
file system, general computer term

entry.para: A hierarchically structured network of files and directories that you can access.
The file system defines how files are named.
Spell as two words, do not use filesystem.

varlistentry.term:
folder
folder, general computer term

entry.para: A representation of a directory in a graphical application. Use the term folder when you document applications that use folder icons to represent directories.

To create a folder, choose
File New Folder .

varlistentry.term:
FTP site
FTP site, general computer term

entry.para: A location on the Internet from which you can download files using the File Transfer Protocol (FTP).
All uppercase letters for the term FTP, all lowercase letters in the term site.
You can use Nautilus to browse websites and FTP sites.

varlistentry.term: full screen full screen, general computer term

entry.para: A mode that resizes the item that is displayed on the screen, so that the item is the same size as the screen.
To display the image in full-screen mode, choose ViewFull Screen.

varlistentry.term: Help Help, general computer term

entry.para: An online manual or other item of documentation that a user can access to find out more about how to use the GNOME Desktop. A user can access Help in any of the following ways:

listitem.para: In an application, choose Help > Contents.
For panels and panel objects, right-click on the object, then choose Help from the popup menu.
Start the Help browser application, then navigate to the required Help.

entry.para: To view Help on the Calculator application, start Calculator, then choose ContentsHelp.

In general, you do not need to use the term online Help, as Help is by definition online. However, if there is a possible ambiguity between the Help and another type of documentation, then you can use the adjective online to qualify Help.

varlistentry.term:
hot key
hot key, general computer term

entry.para: A key or combination of keys that starts an application when pressed.
Use the keycap tag for key names.
Use the keycombo tag for key combinations.
To create a hot key, use the Keyboard Shortcuts preference tool.
Do not use any other term for hot key.

varlistentry.term:
icon
icon, general computer term

entry.para: A class of image that represents a functional component of a computer system. In the GNOME Desktop, icons represent menus, menu items, launchers, and other user interface components.
To open a menu from a panel, click on the icon that represents the menu.

varlistentry.term:
image
image, general computer term

entry.para: A visual representation that is electronically rendered. An image might or might not represent a real-world object. Pictures and icons are classes of image.
Choose an image for the panel background.

varlistentry.term:
inode
inode, general computer term

entry.para: A data structure that contains information about individual files in UNIX file systems. Each file has one inode. An inode contains the node, type, owner, and location of a file.
Choose the Date Changed option to display the date that the inode of the item was last modified.
Spell without a hyphen, do not use i-node.

varlistentry.term:
Internet
Internet, general computer term

entry.para: The global association of networks and computers that share information.
Use an initial uppercase letter to refer to the Internet.
Select this option to display Internet time in the applet.

varlistentry.term:
key binding
terms to avoid key binding

listitem.para: Do not use this term. Use the term keyboard shortcut.

varlistentry.term:
keyboard shortcuts
keyboard shortcuts, general computer term

entry.para: A key or combination of keys that provides an alternative to the standard ways of performing an action. The GNOME Desktop provides the following types of keyboard shortcuts:

listitem.para: Access keys, to use the keyboard rather than the mouse.
Hot keys, to use the keyboard rather than the command line.
Shortcut keys, to use the keyboard rather than the user interface.

entry.para: Normal text rules. See also the usage instructions for specific categories of keyboard shortcut.
Use the keycap tag for key names.
Use the keycombo tag for key combinations.
In a table that lists various types of key combinations, the column header for the key combinations should be Keyboard Shortcuts.
Do not use key binding as a synonym for keyboard shortcut.

varlistentry.term:
keypress
keypress, general computer term

entry.para: The action of pressing a key. This term refers to the first part of a keystroke action, that is, pressing the key. The term keypress does not refer to the second part of a keystroke action, that is, releasing the key.
Only accept a keypress after 30 milliseconds.
Do not use keystroke as a synonym for keypress.

varlistentry.term:
keystroke
keystroke, general computer term

entry.para: The action of pressing and releasing a key.
Shortcut keys enable you to perform an action with one or more keystrokes or mouse clicks.
Do not use keypress as a synonym for keystroke.
The left arrow key on the keyboard.

To switch to the workspace to the left of the current workspace, press
Ctrl Alt left arrow .

varlistentry.term:
left mouse button
left mouse button, general computer term

entry.para: The mouse button on the left side of a mouse configured for right-hand use.
In general, you use the left mouse button to control the applet functions.
Do not use mouse button 1 or any other term.

varlistentry.term:
left side
left side, general computer term

entry.para: Use this term to refer to the left side of an item.
The side pane is on the left side of the Nautilus window.

varlistentry.term:
login, noun, adjective
login, general computer term

entry.para: The process of gaining access to a session.
Select this option to display a splash screen on login.
The Options menu lists your login options.

varlistentry.term:
logout, noun, adjective
logout, general computer term

entry.para: The process of terminating a session.
Select this option to display a confirmation dialog on logout.
Use the Sessions preference tool to specify logout behavior.

varlistentry.term:
look-and-feel
look-and-feel, general computer term

entry.para: A general term for the following features of a graphical user interface:

listitem.para: The visual characteristics of the components of the interface.
The characteristics of the interaction between the user and the interface.

entry.para: Nautilus includes background patterns and colors that you can use to change the look-and-feel of the desktop background.
This term is a single noun, do not use look and feel.

varlistentry.term:
man page
man page, general computer term

entry.para: A page of online documentation in UNIX systems.
See the regex man page for further information on how to construct a regular expression.
Spell as two words, do not use manpage.
The meta key on your keyboard. You can use the meta key as a modifier key.
Use the keycap tag with the term Meta when you use the term in a shortcut.

varlistentry.term:
meta key
meta key, general computer term

entry.para: A key that you can use as a modifier key.
The default modifier key is the meta key.

varlistentry.term:
middle mouse button
middle mouse button, general computer term

entry.para: The mouse button between the left mouse button and the right mouse button.
When you release the middle mouse button, floating panels remain in their current position.
Do not use mouse button 2 or any other term.

varlistentry.term:
MIME
MIME, general computer term

entry.para: The MIME type of a file enables applications to read the file.

varlistentry.term:
MIME type
MIME type, general computer term

entry.para: A MIME type identifies the format of a file, and enables applications to read the file. For example, an email application can use the image/png MIME type to detect that a PNG file is attached to an email.
Choose the MIME type option to display the MIME type of the file.

varlistentry.term:
mnemonic
terms to avoid mnemonic

listitem.para: Do not use this term. Use the term access keys.

entry.para: The key on your keyboard that you have defined as the Sawfish modifier key.
Use the keycap tag with the term Modifier when you use the term in a shortcut.
You can define a modifier key for the Sawfish window manager in the Sawfish preference tool.

varlistentry.term:
modifier key
modifier key, general computer term

entry.para: A key that only performs an action when combined with another key.
Alt, Ctrl, and Shift are modifier keys.

varlistentry.term:
mouse keys
mouse keys, general computer term

entry.para: A keyboard accessibility feature. Use the mouse keys features to configure the numeric keypad on your keyboard to emulate mouse actions.
You can specify three mouse keys settings.

varlistentry.term: onscreen, adjective onscreen, general computer term

entry.para: As shown on a display screen.
The desktop contains an onscreen keyboard application to enable users with a physical disability to use the desktop.
Do not hyphenate this term, do not use on-screen.

varlistentry.term: pane pane, general computer term

entry.para: A subdivision of the main working part of a window, where the user works and interacts with the application. A pane provides the impression that you are viewing items that are in a visual plane beneath, or behind, the visual plane of the window.

A pane contains discrete objects, that is, the contents of a pane do not form a unified whole. Typically, a pane displays the work that a user is doing, or routes to that work. A pane is usually surrounded by a frame.
To show the preview pane in Evolution, choose ViewPreview Pane.
To show the side pane in the file manager, choose ViewSide Pane.

varlistentry.term:
permission
permission, general computer term

entry.para: A setting assigned to each file and directory to determine which users have access to read, write, and execute the contents of that file or directory.
You can edit the contents of the system menus if you have write permission for the files and folders that correspond to the system menus.

varlistentry.term:
plugin
plugin, general computer term

entry.para: A supplementary application that you can add to an application to enhance the functionality of the application.
Use the application tag for the names of plugins.

To install a plugin in gedit, choose
Plugins Manager .

varlistentry.term:
pointer
pointer, general computer term

entry.para: A small arrow or other symbol on your screen that you move with a mouse or other pointing device.
The pointer can provide feedback about a particular operation, location, or state.
Do not use the term cursor as a synonym for pointer.
If there is any ambiguity about what the term pointer refers to, use the term mouse pointer.

varlistentry.term:
preference
preference, general computer term

entry.para: A characteristic of an application that determines how the application behaves in relation to the user. Users can choose a preference from a range of alternatives to specify how they want to work with the application. For example, a user can specify whether or not to display a statusbar in gedit.
Applications and applets have associated preferences. Examples of preferences include the following:

listitem.para: Whether all GNOME-compliant applications on the GNOME Desktop display a toolbar.
Whether the Workspace Switcher applet displays workspaces as images or as names.
Whether the Window List applet displays the windows from the current workspace or from all workspaces.

entry.para: To set the preferences for an applet, right-click on the applet, then choose Preferences.

varlistentry.term:
pressed in
pressed in, general computer term

entry.para: Use this term to describe the indented appearance of a button.
The window button remains pressed in until the screenshot capture is complete.
Do not use depressed to describe an indented button.
Do not use depress as a verb to describe pressing a key or mouse button.
The Print Screen key on the keyboard.
To take a screenshot of the GNOME Desktop, press Print Screen.

varlistentry.term:
privileges
privileges, general computer term

entry.para: A set of special permissions granted to a user to perform various operations on a system.
The system administrator is a special user who has privileges to perform all administrative tasks on a system.

varlistentry.term:
program
program, general computer term

listitem.para: Avoid using this term in end-user documentation. See application and command.

varlistentry.term:
prompt, verb
prompt, general computer term

entry.para: Use this verb for a request from the system to the user to perform a specific action to continue.
The system prompts you for your username.
Do not use ask as a synonym for prompt.

varlistentry.term:
property
property, general computer term

entry.para: A characteristic of an object. Each instance of an object can have different property settings. Files, folders, panels, and panel objects have properties. Examples of properties include the following:

listitem.para: The size of a file or folder.
The name of a file or folder.
The icon that represents a file or folder.
Whether a panel is set to autohide.
The command for a launcher.

entry.para: To set properties for the folder, right-click on the folder then choose Properties from the popup menu.

varlistentry.term:
repeat keys
repeat keys, general computer term

entry.para: A keyboard accessibility feature. Use the repeat keys feature to specify the autorepeat settings for your keyboard.
Use the repeat keys feature to enable keyboard autorepeat.

varlistentry.term: reply-to address reply-to address, general computer term

entry.para: An address to which all responses to a message are addressed automatically. Your reply-to address can be the same as your normal email address.
To display your reply-to address in the Compose a message window, choose ViewReply-To Field.
Spell with a hyphen, do not use reply to address.

The carriage return key on the alphanumeric part of the keyboard. In a text editor this key moves the cursor to the start of the next line. You can also use the Return key to initiate an action on the dialog element that has focus.
Use the keycap tag for Return.
To pipe the output of an ls command to a text file, type the following command and press Return: ls | gedit

Sometimes the Return key and Enter key perform the same functions. Refer to the Return key by default, and only refer to the Enter key when the user must press Enter, or when the user is likely to use the numeric keypad.
The right arrow key on the keyboard.

To switch to the workspace to the right of the current workspace, press
Ctrl Alt right arrow .

varlistentry.term:
right mouse button
right mouse button, general computer term

entry.para: The mouse button on the right side of a mouse configured for right-hand use.
Use the right mouse button to modify the applet.
Do not use mouse button 3 or any other term.

varlistentry.term:
right side
right side, general computer term

entry.para: Use this term to refer to the right side of an item.
Edit the details for the bookmark on the right side of the Edit Bookmarks dialog.

varlistentry.term:
root
terms to avoid root

listitem.para: Do not use this term without an associated noun. See root directory, root file system, root folder, root password, root privileges, and root user.

varlistentry.term: root directory root directory, general computer term

entry.para: The top-level directory of the root file system. The root directory includes all other directories. The root directory has no name, and is represented on UNIX systems by the following special character: /
Use the filename tag for a directory that is actually named root, for example, /root.
Click Save to save the file in the root directory.

varlistentry.term: root file system root file system, general computer term

entry.para: The main file system on your computer. The root file system is organized as a hierarchy or tree.
When a file system is mounted, the contents of the file system are accessible from the associated mount point inside the root file system.

varlistentry.term: root folder root folder, general computer term

entry.para: The top-level folder in an archive manager application or file manager application.
Click Create to add the selected files to the root folder of the specified archive.

varlistentry.term: root password root password, general computer term

entry.para: The password for the root user.
Type the root password, then click OK.

varlistentry.term: root privileges root privileges, general computer term

entry.para: A set of permissions that enables you to perform system administration tasks that can normally only be performed by the root user.
You must have root privileges to configure the login screen.

varlistentry.term: root user root user, general computer term

entry.para: The system administrator. The root user has the ability to create or delete user accounts, install software or hardware and perform other system administrator tasks. The username of the root user is root.
Use the literal tag for the username root.
Log in as the root user to change user passwords.
Typically, system administrators log in with the root username.
See also root directory, root password, root privileges.

varlistentry.term:
runlevel
runlevel, general computer term

entry.para: A software configuration under which a selected group of processes exists.
This field contains the command that the system runs to switch to runlevel 2.
Do not use the two-word form run level, or the hyphenated form run-level.

varlistentry.term: screen screen, general computer term

entry.para: The area on a computer monitor, or any other computer device, where text and graphical information is displayed.
Use the slider to specify the speed at which your mouse pointer moves on your screen when you move your mouse.

varlistentry.term:
screensaver
screensaver, general computer term

entry.para: A screensaver is an application that replaces the image on a screen when the screen is not in use. The screensaver application for the GNOME Desktop is XScreenSaver.
When you lock your screen, the screensaver starts.
Use the Mode drop-down list to specify the behavior of the screensaver application.
If screensaver might be confusing in a particular context, use the more specific term screensaver application.
Do not use screensaver display as a synonym for screensaver.

varlistentry.term:
screensaver display
screensaver display, general computer term

entry.para: A screensaver display is the animation that is displayed on your screen when the screen is not in use. You can use your screensaver application to choose a screensaver display to show on your screen when the screensaver application starts.
Some screensavers can capture a frame of video, then manipulate the captured image to create your screensaver display.
Use the Cycle After spin box to specify how long to show a screensaver display before changing to another screensaver display.
Do not use screensaver as a synonym for screensaver display.

varlistentry.term:
screenshot
screenshot, general computer term

entry.para: A file that is an image of an area of the GNOME Desktop, or an image of the entire GNOME Desktop.
Use this slider to specify the delay when you take a screenshot of the entire GNOME Desktop.
Do not use screen shot, screen-shot, screen capture, screen grab, or any other term.
The Shift key on the keyboard.
Press-and-hold Shift, then drag the item to the location where you want the link to reside.

varlistentry.term:
shortcut
shortcut, general computer term

entry.para: An action or a sequence of actions that is performed by a combination of one or more keystrokes or mouse clicks. A shortcut provides a quicker and more convenient way to perform an action than the conventional way to perform the same action.
You can use the Shortcuts dialog pane to view, add, edit, or delete shortcuts from keymaps.

Do not use the following terms as synonyms for shortcut:
Keyboard accelerator
Keyboard shortcut
Only use this term in relation to the Sawfish window manager and preference tool.

varlistentry.term:
shortcut command
shortcut command, general computer term

entry.para: Use to refer to a faster way to run a command.
The macro facility provides up to 99 shortcut commands.

varlistentry.term:
shortcut keys
shortcut keys, general computer term

entry.para: A combination of keys that enables you to jump straight to the action you want to perform, rather than using the user interface to open menus and choose the required command.
Use the keycap tag for key names.
Use the keycombo tag for key combinations.

To open a new file, use the
Ctrl N shortcut keys.
Do not use the term accelerator key for shortcut key.

varlistentry.term:
slow keys
slow keys, general computer term

entry.para: A keyboard accessibility feature. Use the slow keys feature to control the period of time that you must press-and-hold a key before acceptance.
You can specify four slow keys settings.

varlistentry.term:
sort
sort, general computer term

entry.para: To organize items in a list, using a specific characteristic to prioritize the ordering of items in the list. Essentially, sort implies a one-dimensional ordering of items.
You can sort items in the list by several characteristics, such as date of creation, status, name, and so on.
Do not use arrange as a synonym for sort.
The spacebar key on the keyboard.

To open the Window Menu, press
Alt spacebar .
Do not use space or space bar.

varlistentry.term: spam spam, general computer term

entry.para: Unsolicited email messages that you receive. Spam messages are usually intended to promote a product or service. Most email applications enable you to use filters to deal with your spam.
Use filters to deal with spam.

varlistentry.term: spellchecker spellchecker, general computer term

entry.para: A tool that you can use to check the spelling of a document.
To start the spellchecker, choose EditSpell Check Document.
Do not use spellcheck as a verb, use check spelling instead.

varlistentry.term:
sticky keys
sticky keys, general computer term

entry.para: A keyboard accessibility feature. Use the sticky keys feature to perform multiple simultaneous keypress operations by pressing the keys in sequence.
You can specify two sticky keys settings.

varlistentry.term:
strikeout
terms to avoid strikeout

listitem.para: Do not use this term. Use the term strikethrough.

varlistentry.term: strikethrough strikethrough, general computer term

entry.para: A text formatting characteristic where the text appears with a horizontal line through the text.
To apply strikethrough formatting to text, select the text, then choose FormatStyleStrikethrough.
Do not use the term strikeout as a synonym for strikethrough.

varlistentry.term:
superuser
terms to avoid superuser

listitem.para: Do not use this term. Use root user instead.

varlistentry.term: symbolic link symbolic link, general computer term

entry.para: A special type of file that points to another file or folder. When you perform an action on a symbolic link, the action is performed on the file or folder to which the symbolic link points.
When you delete a symbolic link, you delete the link file, not the file to which the symbolic link points.
You can shorten symbolic link to link when you are clearly referring to a symbolic link.

varlistentry.term:
system administrator
system administrator, general computer term

entry.para: A user with root privileges on a UNIX system.
Your system administrator might set your default Menu Panel according to your local requirements.
The Tab key on the keyboard.

To switch between windows, use the
Alt Tab shortcut keys.

varlistentry.term: thread thread, general computer term

entry.para: A set of email messages, composed of an initial message about a subject and all responses to that message.
When you display your messages by thread, you can view the messages on a particular subject in chronological order.

varlistentry.term:
tile
tile, general computer term

entry.para: To cover an area with objects that do not overlap.
You can use the Background preference tool to tile the desktop with an image.

varlistentry.term:
toggle key
toggle key, general computer term

entry.para: A key that can switch between two states.
The Num Lock, Caps Lock, and Scroll Lock keys are toggle keys.

varlistentry.term:
unavailable
unavailable, general computer term

entry.para: When you cannot interact with a GNOME Desktop interface item, describe the item as unavailable.
The toggle menu items are unavailable when you view a document that contains only one page.
Do not use inactive, dimmed, or grayed out.

varlistentry.term:
UNIX
UNIX, general computer term

entry.para: A multi-user, multitasking operating system. UNIX is a registered trademark of The Open Group. The Open Group spell UNIX in all uppercase.
Developers are the primary users of UNIX time.
Do not use Unix, or any other term, unless you have to directly quote the interface.
The up arrow key on the keyboard.

To switch to the workspace above the current workspace, press
Ctrl Alt up arrow .

varlistentry.term:
websafe color palette
websafe color palette, general computer term

entry.para: The websafe color palette is a general-purpose palette of 216 colors. The websafe color palette is designed to optimize the use of color on systems that support 8-bit color.
Applications that do not use the websafe color palette have less colors available.
The websafe color palette is also called the Netscape color palette and the Netscape color cube. In GNOME documentation, use the term websafe color palette only.

varlistentry.term:
website
website, general computer term

entry.para: A location on the World Wide Web.
You can find the GNOME Documentation Style Guide on the GNOME Documentation Project website.
Spell as one word, do not use web-site, or web site.

varlistentry.term:
World Wide Web
World Wide Web, general computer term

entry.para: A system of Internet servers that support HTML documents. You can click on links in HTML documents to view other documents on the World Wide Web.
You can use Mozilla to browse the World Wide Web.
You can shorten World Wide Web to Web when you are clearly referring to the World Wide Web.

varlistentry.term: zip, noun zip, general computer term

entry.para: An archive format created by an application such as PKZIP or WinZip.
File Roller supports zip files, as well as several other archive formats.
Do not use zip as a verb. Use the verb compress instead.
Do not use zip as a synonym for archive.
